case_title: ADDITIONAL COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX, A.P. vs P.R.N.S. & CO.
appellant: Additional Commissioner of Income Tax, A.P.

accussed_details.name: P.R.N.S. & CO.
allegation: Non-compliance with notices under sections 134(2), 142(1), and 139(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961
Delay in filing income tax returns for assessment years 1962-63, 1963-64, and 1964-65

complaint_summary: The appellant alleged non-compliance with statutory notices and delay in filing income tax returns by the respondent for assessment years 1962-63, 1963-64, and 1964-65, resulting in penal interest and penalties under sections 139 and 271(1)(a) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
investigation_summary: The Income Tax Officer issued notices under section 139(2) for the respective assessment years. Returns were filed late, leading to assessments under section 144. The Appellate Tribunal later directed reframing of assessments, but penal interest and penalties were imposed.

judgment_summary.decision: Question answered in favor of revenue and against assessee.
judgment_summary.reasoning: Mistake under Section 154 requires obvious error, not debatable legal points.

Decision_or_verdict: In favor of the revenue and against the assessee.
legal_arguments: The respondent argued that penal interest under section 139 could not be charged without an application for extension of time in Form No. 6, citing Kishanlal Haricharan v. Income Tax Officer [1971] 82 ITR 660 (AP).
The appellant contended that the issue was debatable and not a mistake apparent on the record, relying on T.S. Balaram v. Volkart Brothers [1971] 82 ITR 50 (SC).
citations: Kishanlal Haricharan v. Income Tax Officer [1971] 82 ITR 660 (AP)
T.S. Balaram v. Volkart Brothers [1971] 82 ITR 50 (SC)
Progressive Engineering Co. v. Income Tax Officer [1976] 105 ITR 226 (AP)
key_issues: Applicability of section 154 for rectification of penal interest charged under section 139.
Interpretation of section 139 regarding extension of time for filing returns.

maxims.Illustration (e) of Section 114 of the E: Presumption that official acts have been regularly performed.

legal_terms.Penal Interest: Interest charged for delay in compliance with statutory requirements.
legal_terms.Rectification: Correction of mistakes apparent on the record under section 154.

words_and_phrases.Mistake Apparent on the Record: An obvious and patent mistake not requiring extensive reasoning.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the applicability of penal interest under section 139 and rectification under section 154 of the Income Tax Act, 1961. The court ruled in favor of the revenue, holding that the alleged mistake was debatable and not apparent on the record.
legal_question: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the interest charged under section 139 for the assessment years 1962-63, 1963-64 and 1964-65 is liable to be cancelled under section 154 of the Income Tax Act, 1961?

procedural_history.rectification_request: Filed under Section 154 to delete interest
procedural_history.rectification_rejection: Income Tax Officer rejected citing no apparent mistake
procedural_history.tribunal_decision: Accepted assessee's contention citing Andhra Pradesh High Court precedent

key_precedents.case_name: Kishanlal Haricharan v. Income Tax Officer
key_precedents.principle: Interest under Section 139 chargeable only if extension of time requested.
Mistake apparent from record must be obvious and not debatable.

key_precedents.case_name: Progressive Engineering Co. v. Income Tax Officer
key_precedents.principle: Section 139(4) applies for returns filed beyond due dates.

costs_awarded: Assessee to pay costs to Commissioner of Income Tax
